Title: Human facial expression recognition using two-dimensional non-negative matrix factorization
Affiliations: Information Technology, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebon Jeruk Raya 27, Kebon Jeruk Jakarta Barat 11530, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Salim, W., Information Technology, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebon Jeruk Raya 27, Kebon Jeruk Jakarta Barat 11530, Indonesia; Santika, D.D., Information Technology, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebon Jeruk Raya 27, Kebon Jeruk Jakarta Barat 11530, Indonesia
Abstract: NMF is one of the new developed methods which is made to make the part-based representation of nonnegative data, for example the image of human face. NMF can reduce the dimension of highly dimensional data such as multimedia data. In many researches, NMF can also be used as classification technique which is done by utilizing the extracted feature from NMF process. So far, NMF and its variation such as LNMF has been used to classify human facial expression. Unfortunately, for high dimensional data such as human faces, those methods are computationally expensive. This paper mainly discuss about the human facial expression recognition technique using 2DNMF. This research is done by implementing 2DNMF for facial expression recognition and comparing its result to that of NMF and LNMF. From the experimental result, it can be concluded that 2DNMF can be used for human facial expression recognition with better accuracy and much efficient time. © 2012 Elsevier B.V.

Title: NMF coefficient and bilinear space projection as features for human facial expression recognition
Affiliations: Information Technology, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebon Jeruk Raya 27, Kebon Jeruk Jakarta Barat 11530, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Salim, W., Information Technology, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebon Jeruk Raya 27, Kebon Jeruk Jakarta Barat 11530, Indonesia; Agung, A., Information Technology, Bina Nusantara University, Jl. Kebon Jeruk Raya 27, Kebon Jeruk Jakarta Barat 11530, Indonesia
Abstract: NMF is one of the new developed methods which is made to make the part-based representation of nonnegative data, for example the image of human face. NMF can reduce the dimension of highly dimensional data such as multimedia data. In many researches, NMF can also be used as classification technique which is done by utilizing the extracted feature from NMF process. This paper discuss about the human face expression classification technique using NMF and LNMF. This research has been done using NMF coefficient and bilinear projection of face image. Some researches showed us the using of NMF coefficient in classification though some of them did their research using bilinear space projection. This research is conducted by simulating face expression recognition to the two available approaches and then comparing the accuracy and time efficiency aspect of the two methods. Through this research, it can be concluded that the use of NMF coefficient results in better accuracy compared to bilinear space projection, but bilinear space projection has better time efficiency. © 2012 Elsevier B.V.
Author Keywords: Bilinear space; Face expression recognition; Nmf
References: Li, S.Z., Hou, X.W., Zhang, H.J., Learning spatially localized, parts-based representation (2001) Int. Conf. Authors: Park E., Kim B., Salim W., Cheok A.D.
Title: Magic Asian art
Source title: Conference on Human Factors in Computing Systems - Proceedings
Affiliations: Interaction and Entertainment Research Center, Nanyang Technological University, 50 Nanyang Drive, Singapore 637553, Singapore; Digital Media Lab., Information and Communications University, 517-10 Dogok-dong, Gangnam-gu, Seoul, South Korea
Authors with affiliations: Park, E., Interaction and Entertainment Research Center, Nanyang Technological University, 50 Nanyang Drive, Singapore 637553, Singapore; Kim, B., Digital Media Lab., Information and Communications University, 517-10 Dogok-dong, Gangnam-gu, Seoul, South Korea; Salim, W., Interaction and Entertainment Research Center, Nanyang Technological University, 50 Nanyang Drive, Singapore 637553, Singapore; Cheok, A.D., Interaction and Entertainment Research Center, Nanyang Technological University, 50 Nanyang Drive, Singapore 637553, Singapore
Abstract: Throughout history, paintings have had a static perspective, as determined by the artist. Nowadays, viewers are not passive anymore. This proposal focuses on dynamic painting, and active audiences. Magic Asian Art allows viewers to enjoy dynamic Asian painting, and furthermore, each audience recreates the same painting according to their personal preference or the impression of a painting. It is quite similar that conductor conducts an orchestra for the same music differently. We extract viewer's intension based on the emotional status or impression of the painting by using gaze tracker and the painting will be more dynamic and fun. Magic Asian Art is neither movies by cinematographer, nor video games by an algorithm, but novel interactive painting media by each user.
Author Keywords: Animation; Gaze tracking; Interactive painting; Nonphotorealistic rendering
Index Keywords: Gaze tracker; Gaze tracking; Non-Photorealistic Rendering; ON dynamics; Personal preferences; Video game; Animation; Human engineering; Painting
